What is discrete mathematics?

It is also known as Mathematics for computer science. Sometimes finite mathematics, or concrete mathematics.

Discrete mathematics is the study of numerable sets, it is distinct from others. – such as integers, graphs, and statements in logic.
  • Numerable. From Latin numerābilis.
    • (mathematics) In one to one correspondence with the set of natural integers.

Collins Dictionary

Wiki

https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/numerable

https://www.dictionary.com/browse/numerable?s=t

https://wikidiff.com/countable/numerable#:~:text=As adjectives the difference between,able to be counted%3B countable.

Discrete. "separate, distinct from others," late 14c., from Old French discret, discre, and directly from Latin discretus "separated;" see discreet. Related: Discretely; discreteness. https://www.etymonline.com/word/discrete

Sets

Definitions

Level 1.

Collection. A group of objects of one type that have been collected by one person or in one place. Oxford dictionary.

Object. The objects are sometimes referred to as elements or members. Elements are unique.

Level 2.

Group. A number of people or things that are located close together or are considered or classed together. Oxford dictionary.

Level 3.

Number - The content of a statement of number is an assertion about a concept. [source: The Foundations of Arithmetic, §55, Engl.transl. page 67].

How to use sets?

TAG is the set of all elements such that element checks properties\text{TAG is the set of all elements such that element checks properties}TAG is the set of all elements such that element checks properties﻿.

Finite sets. E.g. A={1,2,3,4}A=\{\text{1,2,3,4}\}A={1,2,3,4}﻿

Either infinite or large finite sets. E.g. A={x∣x is positive, even integer}A=\{x|x\text{ is positive, even integer} \}A={x∣x is positive, even integer}﻿

Mathematical logic

Key ideas

Logic is the basis of all reasoning.

Classical Propositional Logical

A proposition is a communicated declarative sentence that is either true or false, but not both. Remember structure no content.
  • Don't use "preposition" as synonymous with "proposition". A preposition is a word such as 'by', 'for', 'into', or 'with' which usually has a noun group as its object. Collins.
  • Other views of propositions. A proposition is the meaning expressed by statements.
  • Some people use statements and propositions interchangeably.
  • The following statements are propositions
    • 2+3=52+3=52+3=5﻿
    • 1+1=31+1=31+1=3﻿
    • P=NP This is either true or false (but not both), but you don't know.
    • for all x∈Rx\in Rx∈R﻿, x>0x>0x>0﻿ then x2>0x^2>0x2>0﻿
    • Sun leaves tomorrow.
    • ddxex=ex\dfrac{d}{dx}e^x=e^xdxd​ex=ex﻿
    • She loves him.
    • Whenever Juney barks, Ralph gets mad.

  • Moreover, the definition excludes statements such as
    • Read 'Cogito ergo sum' in Discourse on the Method. (command)
    • Let's go to the beach tomorrow. (proposal)
    • God'll help you! (exclamation)
    • 2+3=5?2+3=5?2+3=5?﻿ (question)
    • P(x):=x+4=6P(x):=x+4=6P(x):=x+4=6﻿ (indeterminate declarative sentence). It's a predicate.
    • if x>0x>0x>0﻿, then x2>0x^2>0x2>0﻿
    • f(x)=x2f(x)=x^2f(x)=x2﻿ (indeterminate declarative sentence)
    • This sentence is false. A paradox is not a statement.

You gonna use variables to represent prepositions, thus as you use letters in algebra. e.g.

The Connectives of Propositional Logic. In short, Logical formulas

Definition.

Let ppp﻿ and qqq﻿ be propositions.

NameDenotationMeaning
Conjunctionp∧qp \land qp∧q﻿ p && qp and q
Disjunctionp∨qp \lor qp∨q﻿ p || qp or q. Inclusive-or
Negation!pnot p

Worked examples

  • Write the negation of the proposition.
    • Ten heads were obtained when you flip 10 times a coin.

      P(flipped coin)=flipped coin is a headP(\text{flipped coin} )=\text{flipped coin is a head} P(flipped coin)=flipped coin is a head﻿

      ¬P(flipped coin)=flipped coin is a tail\lnot P(\text{flipped coin} )=\text{flipped coin is a tail} ¬P(flipped coin)=flipped coin is a tail﻿

      By Morgan Law

      ¬(∀flipped coin P(flipped coin))=∃flipped coin ¬P(flipped coin)\lnot(\forall \text{flipped coin } P(\text{flipped coin} ))= \exists \text{flipped coin } \lnot P(\text{flipped coin})¬(∀flipped coin P(flipped coin))=∃flipped coin ¬P(flipped coin)﻿

      In plain English, the following propositions are equivalent

      Ten heads were not obtained.

      Some flipped coins were not head.

      Some flipped coins were tail.

      At least one flipped coin was tail.

    • Some heads were obtained when you flip 10 times a coin.

      P(flipped coin)=flipped coin is a headP(\text{flipped coin} )=\text{flipped coin is a head} P(flipped coin)=flipped coin is a head﻿

      ¬P(flipped coin)=flipped coin is a tail\lnot P(\text{flipped coin} )=\text{flipped coin is a tail} ¬P(flipped coin)=flipped coin is a tail﻿

      By Morgan Law

      ¬(∃flipped coin P(flipped coin))=∀flipped coin ¬P(flipped coin)\lnot (\exists \text{flipped coin } P(\text{flipped coin}))= \forall\text{flipped coin } \lnot P(\text{flipped coin})¬(∃flipped coin P(flipped coin))=∀flipped coin ¬P(flipped coin)﻿

      In plain English, the following propositions are equivalent

      At least one head was not obtained.

      Some heads were not obtained.

      All the flipped coins were not heads.

      No flipped coin was head.

      All the flipped coins were tail.

    • Some heads HHH﻿ and some tails TTT﻿ were obtained.

      The above proposition is equivalent to

      U={x∣x∈H or x∈T}U=\{x|x\in H \text{ or } x\in T\}U={x∣x∈H or x∈T}﻿

      H∪T=UH\cup T=UH∪T=U﻿ Because the flipped coins are either head or tail.

      H∩T=∅H\cap T=\emptyH∩T=∅﻿ Because the coin is either head or tail, but not both.

      So by complement law

      H∪T=T∁∪T=UH\cup T=T^\complement\cup T=UH∪T=T∁∪T=U﻿

      The negation of the proposition is

      U∁=∅U^\complement=\emptyU∁=∅﻿ Since 0/1 laws.

    • At least one was obtained.

      No head was obtained.

      All the flipped coins were tails.

    • For some positive integer nnn﻿, 19340=n⋅1719340=n\cdot 1719340=n⋅17﻿

      No positive integer nnn﻿, 19340=n⋅1719340=n\cdot 1719340=n⋅17﻿

      All positive integers nnn﻿, 19340≠n⋅1719340\neq n\cdot 1719340=n⋅17﻿

    • Every even integer greater than 4 is the sum of two primes.

      Every even integer greater than 4 is not the sum of two primes.

      At least one integer greater than 4 is not the sum of two primes.

  • Determine whether each is true or false.
    • 5<95<95<9﻿ and 9<79<79<7﻿

      true∧falsetrue\land falsetrue∧false﻿

      falsefalsefalse﻿

    • 5<95<95<9﻿ and 9<79<79<7﻿ are not the case.

      ¬false=true\lnot false=true¬false=true﻿

    • 5<95<95<9﻿ or 5<75<75<7﻿ and 9<79<79<7﻿ are not the case.

      true∨whatever=truetrue\lor whatever=truetrue∨whatever=true﻿

  • Formulate the symbol expression in words using p:Lee takes computer science.p:\text{Lee takes computer science.}p:Lee takes computer science.﻿ q:Lee takes mathematics.q:\text{Lee takes mathematics.}q:Lee takes mathematics.﻿
    • ¬p\lnot p¬p﻿

      Lee doesn’t take computer science.

    • p∨¬qp\lor\lnot qp∨¬q﻿

      Lee takes computer science or no mathematics.

    • p∧qp\land qp∧q﻿

      Lee takes computer science and mathematics.

    • p∧¬qp\land \lnot qp∧¬q﻿

      Lee takes computer science, but no mathematics.

    • ¬p∧¬q\lnot p\land \lnot q¬p∧¬q﻿

      Lee takes neither computer science nor mathematics.

  • Formulate the symbolic expression in words using p:Today is Mondayp:\text{Today is Monday}p:Today is Monday﻿. q:It is raining.q:\text{It is raining.}q:It is raining.﻿ r:It is hot.r:\text{It is hot.}r:It is hot.﻿
    • p∨qp\lor qp∨q﻿

      Today is Monday or raining.

    • ¬(p∨q)∧r\lnot(p\lor q)\land r¬(p∨q)∧r﻿

      Today is neither Monday nor raining, but it is hot.

    • (p∧(q∨r))∧(r∨(q∨p))(p\land(q\lor r))\land(r\lor(q\lor p))(p∧(q∨r))∧(r∨(q∨p))﻿

      Today is Monday and it’s raining or hot, but it’s hot, raining, or Monday.

  • At one time, the following ordinance was in effect in Naperville, Illinois: “It shall be unlawful for any person to keep more than three [3] dogs and three [3] cats upon his property within the city.” Was Charles Marko, who owned ﬁve dogs and no cats, in violation of the ordinance? Explain. https://www.chicagotribune.com/news/ct-xpm-1990-10-12-9003250777-story.html

    Yes.

    Informally, if you have five dogs, then you’re keeping more than three dogs.

    Formally dogs,cats∈Ndogs,cats\in Ndogs,cats∈N﻿

    is_lawful(dogs,cats)=dogs≤3∧cats≤3is\_lawful(dogs,cats)=dogs\le3 \land cats\le3 is_lawful(dogs,cats)=dogs≤3∧cats≤3﻿

    is_lawful(5,0)=dogs≤3∧cats≤3=false∧true=falseis\_lawful(5,0)=dogs\le3 \land cats\le3 =false\land true=falseis_lawful(5,0)=dogs≤3∧cats≤3=false∧true=false﻿

    Maybe Charles Marko thought government counts in total such that

    is_lawful(dogs,cats)=dogs+cats≤6is\_lawful(dogs,cats)=dogs+cats\le6is_lawful(dogs,cats)=dogs+cats≤6﻿

    but his ordinance interpretation fails; the government doesn’t say it explicitly, and we don’t assume anything from the text.

    Although attorney argues that is possible to change andandand﻿ to ororor﻿, if you follow connectives of propositional strictly; it is a mistake.

    is_lawful(dogs,cats)=dogs≤3∧cats≤3≠dogs≤3∨cats≤3is\_lawful(dogs,cats)=dogs\le3 \land cats\le3 \neq dogs\le3 \lor cats\le3 is_lawful(dogs,cats)=dogs≤3∧cats≤3=dogs≤3∨cats≤3﻿

Truth tables

  • Created by Charles Sanders Peirce. Popularized by Ludwig Wittgenstein in his Tractatus Logico-Philosophicus.

See "truth"

Truth table generator

When you wish to provide a conclusion (or proof in mathematics), you must use chain statements throughout logical consequences (or connectives, methods, and pieces of evidence) from a base set of previous results – such as axioms, theorems, and definitions.

value judgment

Conditional propositions and logical equivalence

If ppp﻿ and qqq﻿ are propositions, the proposition

is called a conditional proposition and is denoted p  ⟹  qp\implies qp⟹q﻿.

pqp  ⟹  qp\implies qp⟹q﻿Comments
TTTYou must prove this by assuming the antecedent.
TFFYou don’t prove this since the conclusion is false.
FTTTrue by default or vacuously true, so you don’t prove this.
FFTTrue by default or vacuously true, so you don’t prove this.
  • Sufficient condition. If A then B. B whenever the occurrence of A is all that is needed for the occurrence of B. A guarantees B, but B might be achieved in other ways.

If X is a cat, then X is an animal.

  • Necessary condition. A cannot occur without the occurrence of B, but B doesn’t guarantee A.

If not B then not A.

If X is not an animal, then X is not a cat.

If X is a cat, then X is an animal.

Si P, entonces Q. P: X es Y. Q: Z es W.

Si X es Y, entonces Z es W.

P es una condicion suficiente para que ocurra Q. Q ocurre porque P. P no es una condicion necesaria para que ocurra Q. Q puede ocurrir sin necesidad de que ocurra P. P garantiza Q, pero Q puede lograrse de otras maneras. Siempre que ocurra P, pasara Q. La implicacion no es un argumento, sino su sintesis. Es el fundamento para las inferencias.

Analisis de la tabla de verdad: True => True True True => False False Si sabemos que (P=>Q es falso) entonces P es verdaero y Q es Falso. True =>

Si no Q, no P. Si no ocurre Q es una condicion suficiente para que no haya pasado P.

no P o Q.

A common mistake is no P ⇒ no Q, it is a mistake because Q can occur if P doesn’t happen.

Worked examples

Restate each proposition in the form of a conditional proposition.

  • Joey will pass the discrete mathematics exam if he studies hard.

    p: Joey will pass the discrete mathematics exam

    q: He studies hard.

    q  ⟹  pq\implies p q⟹p﻿

  • Rosa may graduate if she has 160 quarter-hours of credit.

    p: Rosa may graduate.

    q: she has 160 quarter-hours of credit.

    q  ⟹  pq\implies pq⟹p﻿

  • A necessary condition for Fernando to buy a computer is that he obtain $2000.

    p: Fernando to buy a computer.

    q: He obtains $2000.

    A necessary condition for ppp﻿ is qqq﻿.

    not q then not p

    p  ⟹  qp \implies qp⟹q﻿

  • A sufficient condition for Katrina to take the algorithms course is that she pass discrete mathematics.

    p: Katrina to take the algorithms course.

    q: She passes discrete mathematics.

    A sufficient condition for ppp﻿ is qqq﻿.

    q  ⟹  pq \implies pq⟹p﻿

  • Getting that job requires knowing someone who knows the boss.

    p: Getting that job.

    q: Knowing someone who knows the boss.

    A necessary condition for getting a job is knowing someone who knows the boss.

    A necessary condition for p is q.

    p  ⟹  qp \implies qp⟹q﻿

  • You can go to the Super Bowl unless you can’t afford the ticket.

    p: You can go to the Super Bowl.

    q: You can afford the ticket.

    p unless not q

    p except on the condition that not q

    A necessary condition for ppp﻿ is not (not qqq﻿).

    A necessary condition for ppp﻿ is q.

    p  ⟹  qp\implies qp⟹q﻿

  • You may inspect the aircraft only if you have the proper security clearance.

    p: You may inspect the aircraft.

    q: You have the proper security clearance.

    A necessary condition for p is q.

    if not q, not p.

    if p, then q.

    • When better cars are built, Buick will build them.

      p: Better cars are built

      q: Buick will build them

      If p then q

  • The audience will go to sleep if the chairperson gives the lecture.

    p: The audience will go to sleep.

    q: The chairperson gives the lecture.

    q  ⟹  pq\implies pq⟹p﻿

  • The program is readable only if it is well structured.

    p: The program is readable.

    q: It is well structured.

    p  ⟹  qp\implies qp⟹q﻿

  • A necessary condition for the switch to not be turned properly is that the light is not on.

    p: The switch is turned properly.

    q: The light is on.

    A necessary condition for not p is that not q.

    if q then p.

    q  ⟹  pq\implies pq⟹p﻿

Represent the given proposition symbolically

Argument

Rules of Inference

Worked examples

Formulate the following arguments symbolically and determine whether each is valid.

Let

p: I study hard.

q: I get A’s.

r: I get rich.

  • If I study hard, then I get A’s. I study hard. Therefore, I get A’s.

    p  ⟹  qp\implies qp⟹q﻿

    ppp﻿

    ∴q\therefore q∴q﻿

    It’s a valid argument because the argument uses the modus ponens.

  • If I study hard, then I get A’s. If I don’t get rich, then I don’t get A’s. Therefore, I get rich.

    p  ⟹  qp\implies q p⟹q﻿

    ¬r  ⟹  ¬q\lnot r\implies \lnot q¬r⟹¬q﻿

    ∴r\therefore r∴r﻿

    From ¬r  ⟹  ¬q\lnot r\implies \lnot q¬r⟹¬q﻿ contrapositive, we may use Hypothetical syllogism to conclude rrr﻿. Thus the conclusion rrr﻿ follows from the hypotheses and the argument is valid.

    p  ⟹  qp\implies q p⟹q﻿

    q  ⟹  rq \implies rq⟹r﻿

    ∴r\therefore r∴r﻿

  • I study hard if and only if I get rich. I get rich. Therefore, I study hard.

    Argument (I)

    p  ⟺  rp\iff r p⟺r﻿

    rrr﻿

    ∴p\therefore p∴p﻿

    By Disjunctive syllogism

    (p  ⟹  r)∧(r  ⟹  p)(p\implies r) \land (r\implies p)(p⟹r)∧(r⟹p)﻿

    ¬(p  ⟹  r)\lnot(p\implies r)¬(p⟹r)﻿

    ∴r  ⟹  p\therefore r \implies p∴r⟹p﻿

    By Modus ponens, (1) is valid

    r  ⟹  pr \implies pr⟹p﻿

    rrr﻿

    ∴p\therefore p∴p﻿

  • If I study hard or I get rich, then I get A’s. I Get A’s. Therefore, If I don’t study hard, then I get rich.

    The argument becomes

    p∨r  ⟹  qp\lor r \implies qp∨r⟹q﻿

    qqq﻿

    ∴¬p  ⟹  r\therefore \lnot p \implies r∴¬p⟹r﻿

    It’s invalid because (p∨r  ⟹  q)∧q(p\lor r \implies q)\land q(p∨r⟹q)∧q﻿ is equivalent qqq﻿, and it’s not the conclusion.

  • If I study hard, then I get A’s or I get rich. I don’t get A’s and I don’t get rich. Therefore, I don’t study hard.

    p  ⟹  q∨rp\implies q \lor rp⟹q∨r﻿

    ¬q∧¬r\lnot q \land \lnot r¬q∧¬r﻿

    ∴¬p\therefore \lnot p∴¬p﻿

    It’s a valid argument since modus tollens application

    p  ⟹  q∨rp\implies q \lor rp⟹q∨r﻿

    ¬(q∨r)  ⟹  ¬p\lnot (q \lor r) \implies \lnot p¬(q∨r)⟹¬p﻿

Proofs

What is the proof?

Proof. A finite sequence of statements (called well-formed formulas in the case of a formal language), each of which is a previous result -axiom, an assumption, experiments, or theorems- in the sequence by a rule of inference.

Axiom. Simple postulate or assumption based on a priori knowledge and free contradictions.

Theorems. Important true statements.

Lemma. Preliminary statements.

Corollary. Statements that follow a few logical steps from the theorem.

https://mathoverflow.net/questions/18352/theorem-versus-proposition

Good proofs

  • State your game plan.
  • Keep a linear flow.
  • A proof is an essay, not a calculation.
  • Avoid excessive symbolism.
  • Revise and simplify.
  • Introduce notation thoughtfully.
  • Structure long proofs.
  • Be wary of the “obvious.”
  • Finish.

Cardinality Rules

The Bijection Rule

Bijection := one-to-one correspondence

Each element of one set is paired with exactly one element of the other set, and each element of the other set is paired with exactly one element of the first set.

What does it mean to write |A| = n?

It means that there is a bijection f : A → {1, . . . , n}

MIT OpenCourseWare. 2016. 3.3.3 Counting with Bijections: Video. YouTube. Retrieved May 25, 2021 from https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=n0lce1dMAh8‌

The Bijection Rule or Equinumerosity

Let S and T be two finite sets. If there exists one-to-one correspondence (or bijection) between them, from S to T, if and only if ∣S∣=∣T∣|S|=|T|∣S∣=∣T∣﻿ i.e. S and T have the same number of elements. This is taken as the definition.

https://www.cs.colostate.edu/~cs220/summer19/slides/16_bijection_rule.pdf

Counting Sequences

Multiplication Principle or Product Rule

P1×P2×...×Pn={(p1,p2,...pn)∣p1∈P1,p2∈P2,...,pn∈Pn}=all sequencesP_1\times P_2\times ... \times P_n=\{(p_1,p_2,...p_n)|p_1\in P_1,p_2 \in P_2,...,p_n\in P_n\}=\text{all sequences}P1​×P2​×...×Pn​={(p1​,p2​,...pn​)∣p1​∈P1​,p2​∈P2​,...,pn​∈Pn​}=all sequences﻿ called Cartesian product.

Thus, if P1,P2,⋯ ,PnP_1,P_2,\cdots ,P_nP1​,P2​,⋯,Pn​﻿ are finite sets, then

For example, if A={x,y,z}A=\{x,y,z\}A={x,y,z}﻿ and B={1,2,3}B=\{1,2,3\}B={1,2,3}﻿

A×B={(x,1),(x,2),(x,3),(y,1),(y,2),(y,3),(z,1),(z,2),(z,3)}A\times B=\{(x,1),(x,2),(x,3),(y,1),(y,2),(y,3),(z,1),(z,2),(z,3)\}A×B={(x,1),(x,2),(x,3),(y,1),(y,2),(y,3),(z,1),(z,2),(z,3)}﻿

∣A×B∣=∣A∣⋅∣B∣=3⋅3=9|A\times B|=|A|\cdot|B|=3 \cdot 3=9∣A×B∣=∣A∣⋅∣B∣=3⋅3=9﻿

Key ideas

  • When we're counting since cardinality ∣A∣|A|∣A∣﻿ is more important than the set A={a0,a1,...,an}A=\{a_0,a_1,...,a_n\}A={a0​,a1​,...,an​}﻿. We will ignore writing it.
  • No decision might be part b of the set. When your problem says about optional something. A={a0,a1,...,an,noA}A=\{a_0,a_1,...,a_n,noA\}A={a0​,a1​,...,an​,noA}﻿
  • If repetitions are allowed, ∣A∣repetitions|A|^{repetitions}∣A∣repetitions﻿
  • If repetitions are not allowed, You'd remove the last used element such that ∣A∣⋅(∣A∣−1)⋅(∣A∣−2)...|A|\cdot(|A|-1)\cdot(|A|-2)...∣A∣⋅(∣A∣−1)⋅(∣A∣−2)...﻿
  • ∣U∣=∣A∣+∣Ac∣|U|=|A|+|A^c|∣U∣=∣A∣+∣Ac∣﻿

  • How many dinners at Kay’s Quick Lunch (Figure 6.1.1) consist of one appetizer and one beverage?

    ∣Appetizers∣=2|Appetizers|=2∣Appetizers∣=2﻿, ∣Beverages∣=4|Beverages|=4∣Beverages∣=4﻿

    ∣Dinners∣=2⋅4=8|Dinners|=2\cdot4=8∣Dinners∣=2⋅4=8﻿

  • How many dinners at Kay’s Quick Lunch (Figure 6.1.1) consist of an optional appetizer, one main course, and an optional beverage?

    ∣Main courses∣=3|Main\text{ } courses|=3∣Main courses∣=3﻿

    ∣optional appetizers∣=∣appetizers∣+∣no appetizer∣=2+1=3|optional \text{ } appetizers|=|appetizers|+|no\text{ }appetizer|=2+1=3∣optional appetizers∣=∣appetizers∣+∣no appetizer∣=2+1=3﻿

    ∣optional bevarages∣=∣bevarages∣+∣no bevarage∣=4+1=5|optional \text{ }bevarages|=|bevarages|+|no \text{ }bevarage|=4+1=5∣optional bevarages∣=∣bevarages∣+∣no bevarage∣=4+1=5﻿

    ∣Dinners∣=∣main courses∣⋅∣optional appetizers∣⋅∣optional bevarages∣=3⋅3⋅5=45|Dinners|=|main\text{ } courses| \cdot |optional \text{ } appetizers| \cdot |optional \text{ }bevarages|=3\cdot3\cdot5=45∣Dinners∣=∣main courses∣⋅∣optional appetizers∣⋅∣optional bevarages∣=3⋅3⋅5=45﻿

  • How many dinners at Kay’s Quick Lunch (Figure 6.1.1) consist of one appetizer, one main course, and an optional beverage?

    ∣Main courses∣=3,|Main\text{ } courses|=3,∣Main courses∣=3,﻿∣Appetizers∣=2,|Appetizers|=2,∣Appetizers∣=2,﻿ ∣Beverages∣=5|Beverages|=5∣Beverages∣=5﻿

    ∣Dinners∣=3⋅2⋅5=30|Dinners|=3\cdot2\cdot5=30∣Dinners∣=3⋅2⋅5=30﻿

  • A man has eight shirts, four pairs of pants, and five pairs of shoes. How many different outfits are possible?

    Outfit={(shirt,pair of pants,pair of shoes)∣shirt∈Shirts,pair of pants∈Pairs of pants,pair of shoes∈Pair of shoes}Outfit=\{(shirt,pair\text{ } of\text{ }pants,pair\text{ } of\text{ }shoes)|shirt\in Shirts,pair\text{ } of\text{ }pants \in Pairs\text{ } of\text{ }pants,pair\text{ } of\text{ }shoes \in Pair\text{ } of\text{ }shoes\}Outfit={(shirt,pair of pants,pair of shoes)∣shirt∈Shirts,pair of pants∈Pairs of pants,pair of shoes∈Pair of shoes}﻿

    ∣Shirts∣=8|Shirts|=8∣Shirts∣=8﻿, ∣Pairs of pants∣=4|Pairs\text{ } of\text{ }pants|=4∣Pairs of pants∣=4﻿ and, ∣Pairs of shoes∣=8|Pairs\text{ } of\text{ }shoes|=8∣Pairs of shoes∣=8﻿

    ∣Outfit∣=∣Shirts∣⋅∣Pairs of pants∣⋅∣Pairs of shoes∣=8⋅4⋅5=160|Outfit|=|Shirts|\cdot|Pairs\text{ } of\text{ }pants|\cdot |Pairs\text{ } of\text{ }shoes|=8\cdot 4\cdot5=160∣Outfit∣=∣Shirts∣⋅∣Pairs of pants∣⋅∣Pairs of shoes∣=8⋅4⋅5=160﻿

  • Two dice are rolled, one blue and one red. How many outcomes are possible?

    Outcomes={(color,position)∣color∈Colors,position∈Positions}Outcomes=\{(color,position)|color\in Colors,position\in Positions\}Outcomes={(color,position)∣color∈Colors,position∈Positions}﻿

    ∣Colors∣=2|Colors|=2∣Colors∣=2﻿, ∣Positions∣=6|Positions|=6∣Positions∣=6﻿

    ∣Outcomes∣=2⋅6=12|Outcomes|=2\cdot6=12∣Outcomes∣=2⋅6=12﻿

  • The Braille system of representing characters was developed early in the nineteenth century by Louis Braille. The characters, used by the blind, consist of raised dots. The positions for the dots are selected from two vertical columns of three dots each. At least one raised dot must be present. How many distinct Braille characters are possible?

    ∣Dot∣=∣Raised dot∣+∣No raised dot∣=2|Dot|=|Raised \text{ } dot|+|No \text{ } raised \text{ } dot|=2∣Dot∣=∣Raised dot∣+∣No raised dot∣=2﻿

    ∣Dot∣n dots=columns×rows=26=64|Dot|^{n\text{ }dots={columns\times rows}}=2^{6}=64∣Dot∣n dots=columns×rows=26=64﻿ are Braille characters possibles.

  • The options available on a particular model of a car are five interior colors, six exterior colors, two types of seats, three types of engines, and three types of radios. How many different possibilities are available to the consumer?

    ∣Possibilities∣=∣Interior colors∣⋅∣Exterior colors∣⋅∣Seats∣⋅∣Engines∣⋅∣Radios∣=5⋅6⋅2⋅3⋅3=540|Possibilities|=|Interior\text{ } colors|\cdot |Exterior\text{ } colors|\cdot|Seats|\cdot|Engines|\cdot|Radios|=5 \cdot 6 \cdot 2 \cdot 3 \cdot 3=540∣Possibilities∣=∣Interior colors∣⋅∣Exterior colors∣⋅∣Seats∣⋅∣Engines∣⋅∣Radios∣=5⋅6⋅2⋅3⋅3=540﻿

  • How many different car license plates can be constructed if the licenses contain three letters followed by two digits if repetitions are allowed? if repetitions are not allowed?

    Car license plates={(letter,letter,letter,digit,digit)∣letter∈English alphabet,digit∈Decimal numeral system}\text{Car license plates}=\{(letter,letter,letter,digit,digit)|letter \in \text{English alphabet},digit \in \text{Decimal numeral system}\}Car license plates={(letter,letter,letter,digit,digit)∣letter∈English alphabet,digit∈Decimal numeral system}﻿

    ∣English alphabet∣=26|\text{English alphabet}|=26∣English alphabet∣=26﻿

    ∣Decimal numeral system∣=10|\text{Decimal numeral system}|=10∣Decimal numeral system∣=10﻿

    If repetitions are allowed, then

    Car license plates=26⋅26⋅26⋅10⋅10=1757600\text{Car license plates}=26\cdot26\cdot26\cdot10\cdot10=1757600Car license plates=26⋅26⋅26⋅10⋅10=1757600﻿

    If repetitions are not allowed, then

  • How many 7-digit phone numbers are possible, assuming that the first digit can’t be a 0 or a 1?

    phone numers={(digit1,digit2,digit3,digit4,digit5,digit6,digit7)∣digit1∈[2,9],digit2∈[0,9],...}\text{phone numers}=\{(digit_1,digit_2,digit_3,digit_4,digit_5,digit_6,digit_7)|digit_1\in[2,9],digit_2\in[0,9],...\}phone numers={(digit1​,digit2​,digit3​,digit4​,digit5​,digit6​,digit7​)∣digit1​∈[2,9],digit2​∈[0,9],...}﻿

    ∣phone numbers∣=8×107=8000000|\text{phone numbers}|=8\times10^7=8000000∣phone numbers∣=8×107=8000000﻿

  • Re-solve the previous problem, except now assume also that the phone number is not allowed to start with 911

    911 phone numers={(digit1,digit2,digit3,digit4,digit5,digit6,digit7)∣digit1∈[9],digit2∈[1],digit3∈[1],digit4∈[0,9],...}\text{911 phone numers}=\{(digit_1,digit_2,digit_3,digit_4,digit_5,digit_6,digit_7)|digit_1\in[9],digit_2\in[1],digit_3\in[1],digit_4\in[0,9],...\}911 phone numers={(digit1​,digit2​,digit3​,digit4​,digit5​,digit6​,digit7​)∣digit1​∈[9],digit2​∈[1],digit3​∈[1],digit4​∈[0,9],...}﻿

    ∣no 911 phone numbers∣=∣phone numbers∣−∣911 phone numbers∣=(8×107)−104=7990000|\text{no 911 phone numbers}|=|\text{phone numbers}|-|\text{911 phone numbers}|=(8\times10^7)-10^4=7990000∣no 911 phone numbers∣=∣phone numbers∣−∣911 phone numbers∣=(8×107)−104=7990000﻿

Exercises 10–12 ask about strings of length 5 formed using the letters ABCDEFG without repetitions.

  • 10. How many strings begin with the letter F and end with the letter A?

    String={(F,letter,letter,letter,A)∣letter∈{B,C,D,E,G}}String=\{(F,letter,letter,letter,A)|letter_\in \{B,C,D,E,G\} \}String={(F,letter,letter,letter,A)∣letter∈​{B,C,D,E,G}}﻿

    ∣String∣=1⋅5⋅4⋅3⋅1=60|String|=1\cdot5\cdot4\cdot3\cdot1=60∣String∣=1⋅5⋅4⋅3⋅1=60﻿

  • 11. How many strings begin with the letter F and do not end with EB in that order?

    U={(F,letter,letter,letter,letter)∣letter∈{A,B,C,D,E,G}}U=\{(F,letter,letter,letter,letter)|letter\in \{A,B,C,D,E,G\}\}U={(F,letter,letter,letter,letter)∣letter∈{A,B,C,D,E,G}}﻿

    ∣U∣=1⋅6⋅5⋅4⋅3=360|U|=1\cdot6\cdot5\cdot4\cdot3=360∣U∣=1⋅6⋅5⋅4⋅3=360﻿

    StringsEB={(F,letter,letter,E,B)∣letter∈{A,C,D,G}}Strings_{EB}=\{(F,letter,letter,E,B)|letter\in \{A,C,D,G\}\}StringsEB​={(F,letter,letter,E,B)∣letter∈{A,C,D,G}}﻿

    ∣StringsnoEB∣=∣U∣−∣StringsEB∣=348|Strings_{noEB}|=|U|-|Strings_{EB}|=348∣StringsnoEB​∣=∣U∣−∣StringsEB​∣=348﻿

  • 12. How many strings contain CEG together in that order?

Two chess players, A and B, are going to play 7 games. Each game has three possible outcomes: a win for A (which is a loss for B), a draw (tie), and a loss for A (which is a win for B). A win is worth 1 point, a draw is worth 0.5 points, and a loss is worth 0 points.

  • How many possible outcomes for the individual games are there, such that overall player A ends up with 3 wins, 2 draws, and 2 losses?

    A={(win1,win2,win3,draw1,draw2,loss1,loss2),...}A=\{(win_1,win_2,win_3,draw_1,draw_2,loss_1,loss_2),...\}A={(win1​,win2​,win3​,draw1​,draw2​,loss1​,loss2​),...}﻿

    ∣A∣=(73)(42)(22)=210|A|={7\choose 3}{4\choose 2}{2\choose 2}=210∣A∣=(37​)(24​)(22​)=210﻿

  • How many possible outcomes for the individual games are there, such that A ends up with 4 points and B ends up with 3 points?

    A1={(win1,win2,win3,win4,loss1,loss2,loss3),...}A_1=\{(win_1,win_2,win_3,win_4,loss_1,loss_2,loss_3),...\}A1​={(win1​,win2​,win3​,win4​,loss1​,loss2​,loss3​),...}﻿

    A2={(win1,win2,win3,draw1,draw2,loss1,loss2),...}A_2=\{(win_1,win_2,win_3,draw_1,draw_2,loss_1,loss_2),...\}A2​={(win1​,win2​,win3​,draw1​,draw2​,loss1​,loss2​),...}﻿

    A3={(win1,win2,draw1,draw2,draw3,draw4,loss1),...}A_3=\{(win_1,win_2,draw_1,draw_2,draw_3,draw_4,loss_1),...\}A3​={(win1​,win2​,draw1​,draw2​,draw3​,draw4​,loss1​),...}﻿

    A4={(win1,draw1,draw2,draw3,draw4,draw5,draw6),...}A_4=\{(win_1,draw_1,draw_2,draw_3,draw_4,draw_5,draw_6),...\}A4​={(win1​,draw1​,draw2​,draw3​,draw4​,draw5​,draw6​),...}﻿

    ∣All outcomes where A wins by a score of 4∣=∣A1∣+∣A2∣+∣A3∣+∣A4∣=(74)+(73)(42)+(72)(54)+(71)=357|\text{All outcomes where A wins by a score of 4}|=|A_1|+|A_2|+|A_3|+|A_4|={7\choose4}+{7\choose3}{4\choose2}+{7\choose2}{5\choose4}+{7\choose1}=357∣All outcomes where A wins by a score of 4∣=∣A1​∣+∣A2​∣+∣A3​∣+∣A4​∣=(47​)+(37​)(24​)+(27​)(45​)+(17​)=357﻿

  • Now assume that they are playing a best-of-7 match, where the match will end when either player has 4 points or when 7 games have been played, whichever is first. Addition Principle or Sum Rule

If A1,A2,...,AnA_1,A_2,...,A_nA1​,A2​,...,An​﻿ are disjoint sets, then:

∣A1∪A1∪...∪An∣=∣A1∣+∣A2∣+...+∣An∣|A_1\cup A_1\cup ...\cup A_n|=|A_1|+|A_2|+...+|A_n|∣A1​∪A1​∪...∪An​∣=∣A1​∣+∣A2​∣+...+∣An​∣﻿

Inclusion–exclusion principle

If XXX﻿ and YYY﻿ are finite sets, then

The k-to-1 rule or division rule

If B is a finite set and f : A → B maps precisely k items of A to every item of B, then A has k times as many items as B.

https://dspace.mit.edu/bitstream/handle/1721.1/70477/6-042j-fall-2002/contents/readings/ln9.pdf

The division rule is a common way to ignore “unimportant” differences when you are counting things. You can count distinct objects, and then use the division rule to “merge” the ones that are not significantly different.

Permutations

A permutation of n things taken r at a time, written P(n,r), is an arrangement in a row of r things, taken from a set of n distinct things. Order matters.

In your problem, (a0,a1,a2)≠(a1,a2,a0)?(a_0,a_1,a_2)\ne(a_1,a_2,a_0)?(a0​,a1​,a2​)=(a1​,a2​,a0​)?﻿

Example: How many permutations of the letters ABCDEF contain the letters DEF together in anyorder?

Counting Subsets or combinations

A combination of n things taken r at a time, written C(n,r) or n r (“n choose r”) is any subset of r things from n things. Order makes no difference.

In your problem, (a0,a1,a2)=(a1,a2,a0)?(a_0,a_1,a_2)=(a_1,a_2,a_0)?(a0​,a1​,a2​)=(a1​,a2​,a0​)?﻿

The key points to remember in this section are that a permutation takes order into account and a combination does not take order into account. Thus, a key to solving counting problems is to determine whether we are counting ordered or unordered items.

Operator precedence

(),¬,∧,∨,  ⟹  ,  ⟺  (),\lnot, \land, \lor, \implies,\iff(),¬,∧,∨,⟹,⟺﻿

Operator precedence is about associations, no evaluations. You can evaluate how you want, but following operator precedence. When operators have the same precedence, you must associate left to right.

Example:

What do you think about below sentence? Will be either i=1 or i=0?

let i  = 0;
i == 0 || ((i = Math.sqrt(i+1)) == 1 && ++i == 1);
// What will be i's value, i = 0 or i = 1?

Even though &&, (), Math.sqrt() have higher precedence, iii﻿ will be 0 since JavaScript evaluates left hand side first and because T || x = T, it doesn’t evaluate right hand side.
